ground_truth: Lebowski stares at him, dumbstruck. The Dude is encouraged and takes a hurried sip from his drink. Brandt is handing him a letter-sized envelope, which is distended by something inside. The Dude, frowning, untucks its flap, takes out some cotton wadding, and unrolls it. The wadding, undone, reveals a smaller wad of gauze taped up inside. The Dude undoes the tape with his fingernails and starts to unroll the inner package. Between thumb and forefinger, the Dude holds up the contents of the package--a little toe, with emerald green nail polish. The Dude and Walter sit at the counter, both staring off into space, both absently stirring their coffee with little clinking noises. A waitress enters. The Dude has left frame; Walter calls after him as he looks defiantly around. A dripping noise follows. The Dude sits in the bathtub, staring stuporously, a joint pinched in one hand, a washcloth draped over his head. He stares at his toes, which protrude from the soapy water, splayed against the far side of the tub. After the Dude's outgoing message, we hear a dripping noise, and the Dude looks stuporously up, his head swaying. One of them holds a string at the other end of which a small animal skitters excitedly about the floor, as two other men enter behind him. The Dude looks curiously at the small, nattering animal before the man with the string scoops up the marmot and tosses it, screaming, into the bathtub; the Dude screams. The marmot splashes frantically, biting at the Dude in a frenzy of fearful aggression. The three men turn to leave and have reached the Dude's car, where the driver's side exterior has been scraped raw. A policeman hands the Dude a door handle and an exterior rear-view mirror, laughing and agreeing broadly, while the Dude looks sadly through his window at the policeman rocking back on his heels, his raucous laughter muffled by the glass. The Dude, Walter, and Donny sit at the bar, the Dude with a White Russian, Walter with a beer, and Donny eating beer nuts. Walter sadly shakes his head as they leave the Dude sitting morosely at the bar, and he stares. He is middle-aged, amiable, craggily handsome--Sam Elliot, perhaps, with a large Western-style mustache and wearing denims, a yoked shirt, and a cowboy hat. We recognize the voice of The Stranger whose narration opened the movie. The Stranger nods and, waiting for his drink, looks amiably around the bar. His crinkled eyes settle on the Dude, who, still staring down at his drink, shakes his head. The Dude looks at The Stranger as if just now noticing how out of place the cowpoke is, while the Stranger chuckles indulgently and pushes off from the bar.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Lebowski gazes at him, awestruck. The Dude is heartened and takes a hasty sip from his beverage. Brandt is presenting him a letter-sized packet, which is bulging by something inside. The Dude, scowling, untucks its flap, extracts some cotton padding, and unfurls it. The padding, unwrapped, discloses a smaller bundle of gauze taped up inside. The Dude loosens the tape with his fingernails and starts to unfurl the internal bundle. Between thumb and index finger, the Dude holds up the contents of the bundle--a small toe, with emerald green nail lacquer. The Dude and Walter sit at the counter, both gazing off into space, both absentmindedly stirring their coffee with little clinking noises. A waitress enters. The Dude has left frame; Walter calls after him as he looks defiantly around. A dripping noise follows. The Dude sits in the bathtub, staring dazedly, a joint clasped in one hand, a washcloth draped over his head. He gazes at his toes, which jut from the soapy water, spread against the far side of the tub. After the Dude's outgoing message, we hear a dripping noise, and the Dude looks dazedly up, his head swaying. One of them holds a cord at the other end of which a small creature skitters excitedly about the floor, as two other men enter behind him. The Dude looks curiously at the small, chattering creature before the man with the cord scoops up the marmot and tosses it, shrieking, into the bathtub; the Dude shrieks. The marmot splashes frantically, nipping at the Dude in a frenzy of fearful aggression. The three men turn to depart and have reached the Dude's car, where the driver's side exterior has been scraped raw. A policeman hands the Dude a door handle and an exterior rear-view mirror, laughing and agreeing broadly, while the Dude looks sadly through his window at the policeman rocking back on his heels, his boisterous laughter muffled by the glass. The Dude, Walter, and Donny sit at the bar, the Dude with a White Russian, Walter with a beer, and Donny eating beer nuts. Walter sadly shakes his head as they leave the Dude sitting gloomily at the bar, and he gazes. He is middle-aged, affable, ruggedly handsome--Sam Elliot, perhaps, with a large Western-style mustache and wearing denims, a yoked shirt, and a cowboy hat. We recognize the voice of The Stranger whose narration opened the movie. The Stranger nods and, waiting for his drink, looks affably around the bar. His crinkled eyes settle on the Dude, who, still gazing down at his drink, shakes his head. The Dude looks at The Stranger as if just now noticing how out of place the cowpoke is, while the Stranger chuckles indulgently and pushes off from the bar.

test_cases.description: Lebowski is stared at by him, dumbstruck. Encouragement is felt by the Dude, and a hurried sip from his drink is taken by him. Brandt hands him a letter-sized envelope, which distends by something inside. The flap is untucked by the Dude, frowning, and some cotton wadding is taken out and unrolled by him. The wadding is undone and a smaller wad of gauze taped up inside is revealed. The tape is undone by the Dude with his fingernails, and the inner package is started to be unrolled by him. The contents of the package--a little toe, with emerald green nail polish--are held up by the Dude between thumb and forefinger. The counter is sat at by the Dude and Walter, both staring off into space, both absently stirring their coffee with little clinking noises. A waitress is entered by her. Frame has been left by the Dude; he is called after by Walter as he looks defiantly around. A dripping noise is followed by him. The bathtub is sat in by the Dude, staring stuporously, a joint pinched in one hand, a washcloth draped over his head. His toes are stared at by him, which protrude from the soapy water, splayed against the far side of the tub. After the Dude's outgoing message, a dripping noise is heard, and his head sways as he looks stuporously up. The string is held by one of them at the other end of which a small animal skitters excitedly about the floor, as two other men enter behind him. The small, nattering animal is looked at curiously by the Dude before the marmot is scooped up by the man with the string and is tossed, screaming, into the bathtub; the Dude screams. Frantic splashing and biting at the Dude in a frenzy of fearful aggression is done by the marmot. The three men turn to leave and reach the Dude's car, where the driver's side exterior has been scraped raw. A door handle and an exterior rear-view mirror are handed to the Dude by a policeman, who laughs and agrees broadly, while sadly looking through his window at the policeman rocking back on his heels, his raucous laughter muffled by the glass. The bar is sat at by the Dude, Walter, and Donny, the Dude with a White Russian, Walter with a beer, and Donny eating beer nuts. Walter shakes his head sadly as the Dude is left sitting morosely at the bar, and he stares. He is middle-aged, amiable, craggily handsome--Sam Elliot, perhaps, with a large Western-style mustache and wearing denims, a yoked shirt, and a cowboy hat. The voice of The Stranger, whose narration opened the movie, is recognized. The Stranger nods and, waiting for his drink, he looks amiably around the bar. His crinkled eyes settle on the Dude, who, still staring down at his drink, is shaken his head. The Stranger is looked at by the Dude as if just now noticing how out of place the cowpoke is, while indulgent chuckling is done by the Stranger as he pushes off from the bar.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Lebowski stares, stunned. The Dude, encouraged, takes a quick sip. Brandt hands him a bulging envelope. The Dude, frowning, untucks its flap, removes some cotton wadding, and unrolls it to reveal a taped gauze wad. He carefully unwraps it to find a small toe with emerald green nail polish. The Dude and Walter sit, staring into space, absentmindedly stirring coffee. A waitress enters. After the Dude exits, Walter defiantly looks around. The Dude sits in the bathtub, staring dazedly, a joint in hand, washcloth over his head. He stares at his toes in the soapy water. A dripping sound follows the Dude's outgoing message. A man holds a string with a small animal skittering on the floor as two others enter. The Dude curiously watches the animal before it’s tossed into the bathtub, prompting him to scream as it splashes frantically. The men leave, reaching the Dude's scraped car. A policeman hands him a door handle and mirror, laughing, while the Dude looks sadly through the window at him. The Dude, Walter, and Donny sit at the bar; Walter sadly shakes his head as they leave the Dude, who stares. A middle-aged, amiable man resembling Sam Elliott with a large mustache—The Stranger—nods, waiting for his drink. His eyes settle on the Dude, who, shaking his head, notices The Stranger, chuckling and leaving the bar.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Lebowski stares, dumbstruck. The Dude takes a hurried sip. Brandt hands him an envelope with something inside. The Dude untucks the flap, removes wadding, revealing gauze. He undoes it, revealing a toe with green nail polish. The Dude and Walter sit, stirring coffee. A waitress enters, and the Dude leaves. A dripping noise follows. The Dude is in a bathtub, joint in hand, staring at his toes. After his message, he hears dripping, then sees a small animal dragged in, which is tossed into the tub, prompting screams. Three men leave, reaching the Dude's scraped car. A policeman hands the Dude a door handle and mirror, laughing, while the Dude looks sadly through the window. The Dude, Walter, and Donny sit at the bar, with respective drinks and nuts. Walter shakes his head, leaving the morose Dude. A middle-aged, amiable man, resembling Sam Elliot, with a Western mustache and attire, recognized as The Stranger, observes the Dude. The Stranger chuckles and leaves the bar.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Lebowski stands there, staring at him, utterly dumbstruck and in disbelief. Encouraged by the moment, the Dude hastily takes a sip from his drink, as if to steady himself. Meanwhile, Brandt is passing him an envelope of letter-sized dimensions, noticeably bulging with something concealed inside. With a furrowed brow, the Dude carefully untucks the flap of the envelope and retrieves some cotton wadding, which he begins to unroll meticulously. As he unravels the wadding, it reveals a smaller bundle of gauze wrapped neatly inside. The Dude then uses his fingernails to undo the tape securing it and starts unrolling this inner package with deliberate care. Pinched between his thumb and forefinger, the Dude holds aloft the contents of the package, which turns out to be a little toe, painted with striking emerald green nail polish.

Both the Dude and Walter are seated at the counter, their gazes distant and unfocused as each idly stirs their coffee, producing gentle clinking noises that echo in the air. A waitress enters the scene, but the Dude has already left the frame; Walter calls out to him, looking defiantly around, as a dripping noise quietly follows. The Dude now sits in the bathtub, staring in a stupor, with a joint held casually in one hand and a washcloth draping over his head. His eyes are fixed on his toes, which protrude from the soapy water, splayed awkwardly against the far side of the tub.

After the Dude's outgoing message plays, that persistent dripping noise echoes again, prompting the Dude to look up in a daze, his head swaying slightly. Nearby, one of the men holds a string, at the end of which a small animal skitters across the floor with eager excitement. As two other men enter behind him, the Dude observes the small, chattering creature with curiosity. Suddenly, the man with the string scoops up the marmot and, with a scream, tosses it into the bathtub; the Dude yells in shock. The marmot splashes about in a panic, biting at the Dude with a frenzy born of fearful aggression. The three men turn to make their exit and have reached the Dude's car, which bears the scars of a scrape along the driver's side exterior.

Outside, a policeman hands the Dude a car door handle and an exterior rear-view mirror, laughing loudly and nodding in agreement, while the Dude looks on sadly from his window. The policeman's laughter, though raucous, is slightly muffled by the glass, contrasting with the Dude's somber reflection. Inside, the Dude, Walter, and Donny sit together at the bar, where the Dude holds a White Russian, Walter sips a beer, and Donny munches on beer nuts. Walter, with a sad shake of his head, gestures as they depart, leaving the Dude to sit forlornly at the bar, staring off into the distance.

The atmosphere shifts as we focus on a middle-aged man with an amiable demeanor. He is ruggedly handsome and might be Sam Elliot, with a large, Western-style mustache, wearing classic denims, a yoked shirt, and topped with a cowboy hat. This is The Stranger, whose familiar voice narrated the beginning of the movie. The Stranger nods perceptively, and as he waits for his drink, he casts an amiable gaze around the bar. His eyes, crinkled with experience, rest on the Dude, who still stares down at his drink and shakes his head. The Dude glances at The Stranger, as if just realizing how out of place the cowboy figure is in this setting. The Stranger, with a chuckle of indulgence, pushes away from the bar, leaving the Dude to his musings.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Lebowski stands in a state of shock, staring at him with wide eyes, utterly dumbstruck and filled with disbelief at what he sees before him. Riding on the wave of the moment, the Dude hastily takes a sip from his drink, as if hoping the familiar taste will help steady his nerves amidst the confusion. Meanwhile, Brandt is in the process of passing him an envelope of letter-sized dimensions, conspicuously bulging with something concealed inside. With a furrowed brow, the Dude methodically untucks the flap of the envelope and retrieves some cotton wadding, which he begins to unroll with meticulous care. As he continues to unravel the wadding, a smaller bundle of gauze is revealed, wrapped neatly inside. The Dude then uses his fingernails to carefully undo the tape securing it and starts unrolling this inner package, doing so with deliberate and cautious care. Finally, pinched between his thumb and forefinger, the Dude holds aloft the contents of the package, which reveal themselves to be a small toe, painted with striking and garish emerald green nail polish.

Both the Dude and Walter are seated side by side at the counter, their gazes distant and unfocused, each staring blankly into the void as they idly stir their coffee, producing gentle clinking noises that echo softly in the air around them. A waitress enters the scene, but by this time, the Dude has already left the frame entirely; Walter calls out to him, looking defiantly around the space, as a steady dripping noise quietly follows in the background. The Dude now finds himself sitting in the bathtub, staring ahead in a stupor, with a joint held casually in one hand and a washcloth draped over his head. His eyes are fixed intently on his own toes, which protrude from the soapy water in front of him, splayed awkwardly against the far side of the tub.

After the Dude's outgoing message plays, that same persistent dripping noise echoes once again, prompting the Dude to look upward in a daze, his head swaying slightly under the weight of his stupor. Nearby, one of the men holds a string, at the end of which a small animal skitters eagerly across the floor with visible excitement. As two other men enter the room behind him, the Dude observes the small, chattering creature with a sense of growing curiosity. Suddenly, the man with the string swiftly scoops up the marmot and, with a loud scream, tosses it into the bathtub; the Dude responds by yelling in shock. The marmot splashes about in a frenzied panic, biting at the Dude with a frenzy born of fearful aggression. The three men turn to make their brisk exit and have reached the Dude's car, which bears the visible scars of a scrape along the driver's side exterior.

Outside, a policeman approaches and hands the Dude a car door handle and an exterior rear-view mirror, all the while laughing loudly and nodding in agreement, as the Dude looks on sadly from his window. The policeman's laughter, though raucous, is slightly muffled by the glass, contrasting sharply with the Dude's somber, reflective expression. Inside, the Dude, Walter, and Donny are seated together at the bar, where the Dude holds a White Russian, Walter sips a beer, and Donny munches on beer nuts. Walter, with a sad shake of his head, gestures as they prepare to depart, leaving the Dude to sit forlornly at the bar, staring off into the distant space.

The atmosphere shifts focus to a middle-aged man exuding an amiable demeanor. He is ruggedly handsome, possibly resembling Sam Elliott, with a large, Western-style mustache, clad in classic denims, a yoked shirt, and topped off with a cowboy hat. This is The Stranger, whose familiar voice narrated the beginning of the movie. The Stranger nods perceptively and, as he waits for his drink to arrive, he casts an amiable gaze around the bar. His eyes, crinkled with experience, finally rest on the Dude, who continues to stare down at his drink, shaking his head ever so slightly. The Dude glances at The Stranger, as if only now realizing how out of place the cowboy figure is in this particular setting. The Stranger, with an indulgent chuckle, pushes away from the bar, leaving the Dude to his contemplative musings.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Lebowski fixes his gaze on him, utterly dumbstruck, the surprise evident in his wide eyes and slightly parted lips. As if spurred on by this reaction, the Dude quickly lifts his drink and takes a hurried sip, the liquid rushing past his lips as he swallows. In the meantime, Brandt extends his arm, offering a letter-sized envelope, which appears swollen due to something inside pressing against the paper. The Dude accepts it, his face contorting into a frown as he deftly untucks the flap with his fingers. He pulls out a piece of cotton wadding, feeling its texture as he begins to unroll it with care. As the layers of cotton come undone, they reveal a smaller, tightly wrapped wad of gauze, secured with tape. Using his fingernails, the Dude carefully peels away the tape, the adhesive resisting slightly before yielding. He then starts to meticulously unroll the inner package, section by section, until he finally pinches the contents between his thumb and forefinger—a little toe adorned with emerald green nail polish, which he holds up for closer examination. Later, the Dude and Walter find themselves seated at the counter, both lost in their thoughts, their gazes fixed into space while their hands absentmindedly stir their coffee, producing soft clinking sounds. A waitress enters the scene, but the Dude has already left the frame. Walter, feeling the absence, calls after him, his voice echoing as he defiantly glances around. Meanwhile, a dripping noise serves as the backdrop to the Dude, now sitting in the bathtub, his expression vacant and unfocused. He grips a joint between his fingers, while a washcloth is draped over his head. His eyes drop to his toes, which poke out from the soapy water, splayed against the far side of the tub. As the Dude’s outgoing message plays, the dripping noise becomes more pronounced, prompting him to look up with a glazed expression, his head swaying slightly. A string held by one of them quivers, at the other end of which a small animal scampers with excitement across the floor, just as two other men enter the scene behind him. The Dude's curiosity is piqued as he watches the small creature chatter away, but before he can react, the man with the string swiftly scoops up the marmot and hurls it, screaming, into the bathtub; the Dude lets out a scream in response. The marmot splashes wildly, water flying everywhere as it bites at the Dude in a frenzy born of fear and aggression. Having completed their task, the three men turn and begin to depart, reaching the Dude’s car, where the driver’s side exterior bears the marks of a raw scrape. A policeman approaches the Dude, handing him a door handle and an exterior rear-view mirror, all the while laughing and nodding in agreement with himself. The Dude, his face a mask of desolation, peers through the window at the officer, who rocks back on his heels, his laughter raucous but muffled by the barrier between them. Subsequently, the Dude, Walter, and Donny sit together at the bar, each occupied with their chosen distractions—the Dude with a White Russian, Walter nursing a beer, and Donny munching on beer nuts. Walter, his mood somber, gives a shake of his head as they rise to leave, leaving the Dude behind to sit morosely at the bar, his mind adrift. Into this scene walks a middle-aged man, amiable and ruggedly handsome, possibly resembling Sam Elliott, complete with a large Western-style mustache, denims, a yoked shirt, and a cowboy hat. This man is The Stranger, whose voice had narrated the opening of the movie. As he stands at the bar, he nods politely and waits for his drink, his crinkled eyes scanning the room with a sense of warmth and familiarity until they settle on the Dude. Still staring down at his drink, the Dude subtly shakes his head, acknowledging The Stranger’s presence. Their eyes meet, and the Dude seems to register just how out of place this cowboy figure appears in the setting, while the Stranger responds with a chuckle, full of indulgence, before pushing away from the bar, leaving the interaction suspended in time.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Lebowski stares at him, dumbstruck, while the Dude takes a hurried sip from his drink as Brandt hands him a letter-sized envelope distended by something inside. The Dude frowns, opens the envelope, and uncovers a smaller wad of gauze, which he unwraps to reveal a little toe with emerald green nail polish. Later, the Dude and Walter sit absently stirring their coffee at the counter, lost in thought. The Dude leaves, prompting Walter to call after him as a waitress enters, accompanied by a dripping noise. The Dude sits in the bathtub, stuporously staring at his toes protruding from the soapy water, a joint in hand and a washcloth draped over his head. Following a dripping noise, he looks up dazedly. A man enters with two others, holding a string tied to a small animal, which he then scoops up and tosses into the bathtub, leading the Dude to scream as the marmot splashes and bites in panic. The three men leave and reach the Dude's car, which has a scraped exterior; a policeman hands the Dude a door handle and mirror, laughing as the Dude watches, saddened, through the window. At the bar, the Dude sits morosely with a White Russian, Walter shakes his head sadly, and Donny eats beer nuts. As they leave, the amiable, craggily handsome Stranger, who is middle-aged and dressed in Western attire, nods while waiting for his drink. His eyes settle on the Dude, who, noticing the cowpoke's odd presence, shakes his head while the Stranger chuckles and departs.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Lebowski, a wealthy but seemingly disconnected businessman, stares at him, dumbstruck. The Dude, a laid-back slacker known for his easygoing nature, is encouraged and takes a hurried sip from his drink. Brandt, Lebowski's loyal and anxious assistant, is handing him a letter-sized envelope, which is distended by something inside. The Dude, frowning as he often does when pondering the unexpected, untucks its flap, takes out some cotton wadding, and unrolls it. The wadding, undone, reveals a smaller wad of gauze taped up inside. The Dude undoes the tape with his fingernails, stained slightly from previous endeavors, and starts to unroll the inner package. Between thumb and forefinger, the Dude holds up the contents of the package—a little toe, with emerald green nail polish that suggests a recent pedicure likely at a local salon. The Dude and Walter sit at the counter of a typical 24-hour diner, both staring off into space, both absently stirring their coffee with little clinking noises that echo in the quiet establishment. A waitress, a figure reminiscent of classical Americana, enters. The Dude has left frame; Walter, his Vietnam vet friend who often finds himself in needless confrontations, calls after him as he looks defiantly around, always on guard. A dripping noise follows, reminiscent of the earlier chaos. The Dude sits in the bathtub, staring stuporously, a joint pinched in one hand, a washcloth draped over his head as if to shield from his troubles. He stares at his toes, which protrude from the soapy water, splayed against the far side of the tub in idle relaxation. After the Dude's outgoing message on an outdated answering machine, we hear a dripping noise, and the Dude looks stuporously up, his head swaying dizzily. One of them, a member of a bizarre group entangled in The Dude's misadventures, holds a string at the other end of which a small animal skitters excitedly about the floor, as two other men enter behind him, their demeanor both menacing and absurd. The Dude looks curiously at the small, nattering animal before the man with the string scoops up the marmot, often mistaken for a ferret, and tosses it, screaming, into the bathtub; the Dude screams, caught off guard by the sudden intrusion. The marmot splashes frantically, biting at the Dude in a frenzy of fearful aggression, as the chaos envelops the small bathroom. The three men turn to leave and have reached the Dude's car, an old model bearing the scars of many misadventures, where the driver's side exterior has been scraped raw. A policeman hands the Dude a door handle and an exterior rear-view mirror, remnants of the car's former glory, laughing and agreeing broadly, while the Dude looks sadly through his window at the policeman rocking back on his heels, his raucous laughter muffled by the glass. The Dude, Walter, and Donny, their amiable but somewhat oblivious bowling teammate, sit at the bar, the Dude with a White Russian, his signature drink, Walter with a beer, and Donny eating beer nuts, a simple pleasure. Walter sadly shakes his head as they leave the Dude sitting morosely at the bar, and as he stares. He is middle-aged, amiable, craggily handsome—Sam Elliot, perhaps, with a large Western-style mustache and wearing denims, a yoked shirt, and a cowboy hat, embodying the archetype of the American cowboy. We recognize the voice of The Stranger, a mysterious narrator whose voice opened the movie, adding a touch of folklore to the story. The Stranger nods and, waiting for his drink, looks amiably around the bar, his presence both grounding and enigmatic. His crinkled eyes settle on the Dude, who, still staring down at his drink, shakes his head, reflecting the weight of his peculiar journey. The Dude looks at The Stranger as if just now noticing how out of place the cowpoke is, while the Stranger chuckles indulgently, embodying the timeless observer, and pushes off from the bar.

test_cases.description: Lebowski stares at him dumbstruck. The Dude is encouraged and takes a hurried sip from his drink. Brandt is handing him a lettersized envelope which is distended by something inside. The Dude frowning untucks its flap takes out some cotton wadding and unrolls it. The wadding undone reveals a smaller wad of gauze taped up inside. The Dude undoes the tape with his fingernails and starts to unroll the inner package. Between thumb and forefinger the Dude holds up the contents of the packagea little toe with emerald green nail polish. The Dude and Walter sit at the counter both staring off into space both absently stirring their coffee with little clinking noises. A waitress enters. The Dude has left frame. Walter calls after him as he looks defiantly around. A dripping noise follows. The Dude sits in the bathtub staring stuporously. a joint pinched in one hand a washcloth draped over his head. He stares at his toes which protrude from the soapy water splayed against the far side of the tub. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. After the Dude's outgoing message we hear a dripping noise and the Dude looks stuporously up his head swaying. One of them holds a string at the other end of which a small animal skitters excitedly about the floor as two other men enter behind him. The Dude looks curiously at the small nattering animal before the man with the string scoops up the marmot and tosses it screaming into the bathtub. the Dude screams. The marmot splashes frantically biting at the Dude in a frenzy of fearful aggression. The three men turn to leave and have reached the Dude's car where the driver's side exterior has been scraped raw. A policeman hands the Dude a door handle and an exterior rearview mirror laughing and agreeing broadly while the Dude looks sadly through his window at the policeman rocking back on his heels his raucous laughter muffled by the glass. The Dude Walter and Donny sit at the bar the Dude with a White Russian Walter with a beer and Donny eating beer nuts. Walter sadly shakes his head as they leave the Dude sitting morosely at the bar and he stares. He is middleaged amiable craggily handsome. Sam Elliot perhaps with a large Westernstyle mustache and wearing denims a yoked shirt and a cowboy hat. We recognize the voice of The Stranger whose narration opened the movie. The Stranger nods and waiting for his drink looks amiably around the bar. His crinkled eyes settle on the Dude who still staring down at his drink shakes his head. The Dude looks at The Stranger as if just now noticing how out of place the cowpoke is while the Stranger chuckles indulgently and pushes off from the bar.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: Lebowski stares at the cat, dumbstruck. The rabbit is encouraged and takes a hurried sip from its drink. The giraffe is handing the dolphin a letter-sized envelope, which is distended by something inside. The rabbit, frowning, untucks its flap, takes out some cotton wadding, and unrolls it. The wadding, undone, reveals a smaller wad of gauze taped up inside. The rabbit undoes the tape with its fingernails and starts to unroll the inner package. Between thumb and forefinger, the rabbit holds up the contents of the package--a little toe, with emerald green nail polish. The rabbit and the dog sit at the counter, both staring off into space, both absently stirring their coffee with little clinking noises. A dragon enters. The rabbit has left frame; the dog calls after it as it looks defiantly around. A dripping noise follows. The rabbit sits in the bathtub, staring stuporously, a joint pinched in one hand, a washcloth draped over its head. It stares at its toes, which protrude from the soapy water, splayed against the far side of the tub. After the rabbit's outgoing message, we hear a dripping noise, and the rabbit looks stuporously up, its head swaying. One of them holds a string at the other end of which a small animal skitters excitedly about the floor, as two other deer enter behind it. The rabbit looks curiously at the small, nattering animal before the fox with the string scoops up the marmot and tosses it, screaming, into the bathtub; the rabbit screams. The marmot splashes frantically, biting at the rabbit in a frenzy of fearful aggression. The three ducks turn to leave and have reached the rabbit's car, where the driver's side exterior has been scraped raw. A fireman hands the rabbit a door handle and an exterior rear-view mirror, laughing and agreeing broadly, while the rabbit looks sadly through its window at the fireman rocking back on his heels, his raucous laughter muffled by the glass. The rabbit, the dog, and the squirrel sit at the bar, the rabbit with a White Russian, the dog with a beer, and the squirrel eating beer nuts. The dog sadly shakes its head as they leave the rabbit sitting morosely at the bar, and it stares. It is middle-aged, amiable, craggily handsome--a lion, perhaps, with a large Western-style mustache and wearing denims, a yoked shirt, and a cowboy hat. We recognize the voice of the kangaroo whose narration opened the movie. The kangaroo nods and, waiting for its drink, looks amiably around the bar. Its crinkled eyes settle on the rabbit, who, still staring down at its drink, shakes its head. The rabbit looks at the kangaroo as if just now noticing how out of place the cowpoke is, while the kangaroo chuckles indulgently and pushes off from the bar.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Lebowski stares at him, dumbstruck. The Dude is encouraged and takes a hurried sip from his smoothie. Brandt is handing him a postcard-sized package, which is distended by something inside. The Dude, frowning, untucks its flap, takes out some tissue paper, and unrolls it. The tissue paper, undone, reveals a smaller roll of yarn taped up inside. The Dude undoes the tape with his fingernails and starts to unroll the inner package. Between thumb and forefinger, the Dude holds up the contents of the package—a little pebble, with emerald green paint. The Dude and Walter sit at the booth, both staring off into space, both absently stirring their tea with little clinking noises. A hostess enters. The Dude has left frame; Walter calls after him as he looks defiantly around. A rattling noise follows. The Dude sits in the armchair, staring stuporously, a cigarette pinched in one hand, a bandana draped over his head. He stares at his fingers, which protrude from the scratchy fabric, splayed against the far side of the chair. After the Dude's outgoing message, we hear a rattling noise, and the Dude looks stuporously up, his head swaying. One of them holds a rope at the other end of which a small robot skitters excitedly about the floor, as two other men enter behind him. The Dude looks curiously at the small, buzzing robot before the man with the rope scoops up the hamster and tosses it, shrieking, into the armchair; the Dude screams. The hamster flails frantically, nibbling at the Dude in a frenzy of fearful aggression. The three men turn to leave and have reached the Dude's bicycle, where the handlebars have been scraped raw. A clerk hands the Dude a seat cushion and a helmet, laughing and agreeing broadly, while the Dude looks sadly through his window at the clerk rocking back on his heels, his raucous laughter muffled by the glass. The Dude, Walter, and Donny sit at the booth, the Dude with a Mint Julep, Walter with a soda, and Donny eating pretzels. Walter sadly shakes his head as they leave the Dude sitting morosely at the booth, and he stares. He is middle-aged, amiable, craggily handsome—Sam Elliot, perhaps, with a large Western-style mustache and wearing overalls, a knitted sweater, and a sun hat. We recognize the voice of The Stranger whose narration opened the movie. The Stranger nods and, waiting for his cocktail, looks amiably around the booth. His crinkled eyes settle on the Dude, who, still staring down at his drink, shakes his head. The Dude looks at The Stranger as if just now noticing how out of place the cowpoke is, while the Stranger chuckles indulgently and pushes off from the booth.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Lebowski glances at him, amazed. The Dude is invigorated and takes a deliberate gulp from his drink. Brandt is showing him a letter-sized envelope, which is flattened by something inside. The Dude, grimacing, seals its flap, extracts some cotton wadding, and folds it. The wadding, folded, uncovers a smaller wad of gauze wrapped up inside. The Dude peels the tape with his fingernails and begins to pack the inner package. Between thumb and forefinger, the Dude displays the contents of the package--a little toe, with emerald green nail polish. The Dude and Walter recline at the counter, both gazing off into space, both absently tapping their coffee with gentle clinking noises. A waitress exits. The Dude has entered frame; Walter shouts after him as he glances challengingly around. A humming noise echoes. The Dude resides in the bathtub, gazing blankly, a joint gripped in one hand, a washcloth draped over his shoulder. He glances at his toes, which emerge from the soapy water, nestled against the far side of the tub. After the Dude's outgoing message, we hear a humming noise, and the Dude glances blankly up, his head swaying. One of them grips a string at the other end of which a small animal leaps excitedly around the floor, as two other men follow behind him. The Dude observes curiously at the small, chattering animal before the man with the string gathers up the marmot and places it, screeching, into the bathtub; the Dude gasps. The marmot splashes frantically, nibbling at the Dude in a frenzy of fearful panic. The three men prepare to enter and have reached the Dude's car, where the driver's side exterior has been painted raw. A policeman presents the Dude a door handle and an exterior rear-view mirror, chuckling and nodding broadly, while the Dude peers sadly through his window at the policeman swaying back on his heels, his boisterous laughter softened by the glass. The Dude, Walter, and Donny lounge at the bar, the Dude with a White Russian, Walter with a beer, and Donny munching beer nuts. Walter pensively nods his head as they leave the Dude sitting contemplatively at the bar, and he observes. He is middle-aged, amiable, ruggedly charming--Sam Elliot, perhaps, with a large Western-style mustache and wearing denims, a yoked shirt, and a cowboy hat. We distinguish the voice of The Stranger whose narration commenced the movie. The Stranger winks and, expecting his drink, glances cheerfully around the bar. His crinkled eyes focus on the Dude, who, still gazing down at his drink, nods his head. The Dude glances at The Stranger as if just now recognizing how out of place the cowpoke is, while the Stranger laughs softly and steps away from the bar.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description:
The bookshelf gazes at it, astonished. The bicycle is heartened and takes a swift sip from its flower pot. The spatula is offering it a postcard-sized package, which is inflated by something inside. The bicycle, grimacing, untucks its flap, takes out some sandpaper, and unfurls it. The sandpaper, unfurled, unveils a smaller ball of yarn taped up inside. The bicycle unravels the tape with its fingertips and begins to unfurl the inner wrapping. Between thumb and forefinger, the bicycle holds up the contents of the wrapping--a tiny carrot, with sapphire blue stripes. 

The bicycle and the toaster sit at the piano, both staring off into the distance, both absentmindedly stirring their lemonade with little jingling sounds. An umbrella enters. The bicycle has exited the scene; the toaster calls after it as it looks rebelliously around. A ticking noise follows. The bicycle sits in the hammock, staring blankly, a candle clutched in one hand, a napkin draped over its head. It stares at its carrots, which protrude from the bubbly pudding, splayed against the far side of the bowl. After the bicycle's outgoing message, we hear a ticking noise, and the bicycle looks drowsily up, its head swaying. One of them holds a ribbon at the other end of which a tiny leaf skates excitedly about the rug, as two other balloons enter behind it. The bicycle looks inquisitively at the tiny, babbling leaf before the balloon with the ribbon collects the squirrel and tosses it, shouting, into the hammock; the bicycle shrieks. The squirrel splashes wildly, nibbling at the bicycle in a frenzy of nervous excitement. The three balloons turn to leave and have reached the bicycle's scooter, where the passenger's side exterior has been scraped raw. A trumpet passes the bicycle a shoe and an exterior side mirror, chuckling and agreeing broadly, while the bicycle looks forlornly through its curtain at the trumpet swaying on its heels, its boisterous laughter muted by the drapery. 

The bicycle, the toaster, and the kite sit at the bench, the bicycle with a Black Russian, the toaster with a cider, and the kite munching pretzel sticks. The toaster regretfully shakes its head as they leave the bicycle sitting gloomily at the bench, and it stares. It is middle-aged, friendly, ruggedly attractive--James Taylor, perhaps, with a large adventurer-style beard and wearing overalls, a flannel shirt, and a cap. We identify the voice of The Narrator whose speech opened the play. The Narrator nods and, awaiting its lemonade, glances cordially around the bench. Its wrinkled eyes rest on the bicycle, who, still staring down at its teacup, shakes its handle. The bicycle looks at The Narrator as if just now sensing how misplaced the voyager is, while The Narrator laughs kindly and pushes off from the bench.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Lebowski gapes at him, flabbergasted. The Parrot is motivated and takes a quick nibble from his snack. The Artist is sliding him a letter-sized envelope, which is swollen by something inside. The Parrot, grimacing, opens its flap, pulls out some wool padding, and unfurls it. The padding, unfolded, reveals a smaller bundle of silk wrapped up inside. The Parrot unwraps the silk with his beak and begins to unwind the inner package. Between beak and claw, the Parrot holds up the contents of the package--a small feather, with sapphire blue dye. The Parrot and Cat sit at the counter, both staring off into space, both absentmindedly stirring their soup with soft tinkling noises. A bartender arrives. The Parrot has left frame; the Cat calls after him as he glances defiantly around. A dripping sound ensues. The Parrot lounges in the birdbath, gazing lazily, a toothpick held in one claw, a towel draped over his head. He gazes at his feathers, which poke out from the sudsy water, flared against the far side of the bath. After the Parrot's outgoing message, we hear a dripping sound, and the Parrot gazes lazily up, his head wobbling. One of them holds a ribbon at the other end of which a small creature darts eagerly about the ground, as two other people enter behind him. The Parrot gazes inquisitively at the small, chittering creature before the person with the ribbon scoops up the hamster and flings it, squealing, into the birdbath; the Parrot shrieks. The hamster splashes desperately, nipping at the Parrot in a frenzy of frightened aggression. The three people turn to leave and have reached the Parrot's vehicle, where the passenger side exterior has been scraped bare. A firefighter passes the Parrot a trunk handle and a rear-view mirror, chortling and agreeing broadly, while the Parrot gazes sorrowfully through his window at the firefighter rocking back on his heels, his boisterous laughter muted by the glass. The Parrot, the Cat, and the Frog sit at the booth, the Parrot with a Martini, the Cat with a cider, and the Frog munching popcorn. The Cat sadly shakes his head as they leave the Parrot sitting dejectedly at the booth, and he stares. He is mature, affable, ruggedly charming--perhaps Clint Eastwood, with a vast Western-style hat and wearing overalls, a tasseled shirt, and a bolo tie. We recognize the voice of The Narrator whose voice started the film. The Narrator grins and, anticipating his snack, glances cheerfully around the booth. His twinkling eyes settle on the Parrot, who, still staring down at his snack, shakes his head. The Parrot looks at The Narrator as if just now realizing how out of place the cowboy is, while the Narrator chuckles kindly and pushes off from the booth.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: Lebowski gapes at him, bewildered. The Dude is reassured and takes a quick nibble from his meal. Brandt is passing him a magazine-sized folder, which is puffed out by something within. The Dude, scowling, unbuttons its clasp, pulls out some fluffy stuffing, and unfurls it. The stuffing, unrolled, exposes a smaller roll of fabric bound up inside. The Dude peels away the adhesive with his thumbnails and begins to unfurl the interior bundle. Between thumb and forefinger, the Dude lifts the contents of the bundle—a tiny shell, with bright blue paint. The Dude and Walter sit at the table, both gazing into nothingness, both absentmindedly swirling their tea with subtle clattering sounds. A chef enters. The Dude has left the scene; Walter shouts after him as he glances defiantly around. A dripping sound follows. The Dude reclines in the hammock, gazing dreamily, a pencil held in one hand, a towel draped over his head. He stares at his fingers, which protrude from the fuzzy blanket, aligned against the edge of the hammock. After the Dude's outgoing message, we hear a pattering noise, and the Dude looks drowsily up, his head wobbling. One of them holds a ribbon at the other end of which a small bird flutters excitedly about the room, as two other men step in behind him. The Dude looks inquisitively at the small, chirping bird before the man with the ribbon lifts up the rabbit and tosses it, screeching, into the hammock; the Dude yells. The rabbit flounders wildly, pecking at the Dude in a storm of frantic defensiveness. The three men turn to exit and have reached the Dude's scooter, where the passenger's side interior has been scraped clean. A firefighter hands the Dude a wheel and an interior side mirror, chuckling and agreeing heartily, while the Dude looks forlornly through his windshield at the firefighter swaying back on his feet, his booming laughter muted by the glass. The Dude, Walter, and Donny sit at the lounge, the Dude with a lemonade, Walter with a cider, and Donny munching potato chips. Walter despondently shakes his head as they leave the Dude sitting gloomily at the lounge, and he gazes. He is middle-aged, pleasant, ruggedly charming—Sam Elliot, perhaps, with a large Eastern-style cap and wearing trousers, a buttoned vest, and a sports cap. We recognize the voice of The Traveler whose narration opened the film. The Traveler nods and, waiting for his meal, glances cheerfully around the lounge. His smiling eyes settle on the Dude, who, still staring down at his meal, shakes his head. The Dude looks at The Traveler as if just now noticing how out of place the drifter is, while the Traveler chuckles warmly and eases away from the lounge.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Henderson blinks at her, bewildered. The Cat is motivated and takes a quick bite from its sandwich. Vincent is giving her a postcard-sized carton, which is bulging with something inside. The Cat, scowling, loosens its lid, pulls out some wool stuffing, and unravels it. The stuffing, unfurled, exposes a smaller ball of yarn wrapped up inside. The Cat unwraps the yarn with its claws and starts to unwind the inner bundle. Between paw and claw, the Cat holds up the contents of the bundle--a little button, with sapphire blue thread. The Cat and Felix sit at the table, both gazing into the distance, both idly stirring their tea with soft clinking sounds. A chef appears. The Cat has left view; Felix shouts after it as he surveys defiantly around. A ticking noise ensues. The Cat sits in the armchair, gazing hazily, a feather clenched in one paw, a napkin draped over its head. It gazes at its paws, which stick out from the fluffy blanket, stretched against the other side of the armchair. After the Cat's outgoing tune, we hear a ticking noise, and the Cat looks hazily up, its head rocking. One of them grips a ribbon at the other end of which a tiny creature scampers eagerly across the rug, as two other people come in behind him. The Cat looks inquisitively at the tiny, chatterbox creature before the person with the ribbon lifts up the hamster and flings it, shrieking, into the armchair; the Cat yelps. The hamster flails wildly, nibbling at the Cat in a rush of frantic defense. The trio turns to exit and have reached the Cat's bicycle, where the rider's side exterior has been scratched heavily. A firefighter gives the Cat a steering wheel and a side-view mirror, chuckling and nodding heartily, while the Cat gazes wistfully through its sunglasses at the firefighter rocking back on his toes, his boisterous laughter muted by the lenses. The Cat, Felix, and Marty sit at the café, the Cat with a Chocolate Milk, Felix with a lemonade, and Marty munching potato chips. Felix mournfully nods as they leave the Cat sitting gloomily at the café, and it gazes. It is middle-aged, friendly, ruggedly charming--Tim Robbins, perhaps, with a big Sherlock-style monocle and wearing overalls, a pleated shirt, and a fedora. We recognize the voice of The Wanderer whose monologue began the opera. The Wanderer nods and, awaiting his meal, glances kindly around the café. His crinkly stare rests on the Cat, who, still gazing down at its meal, nods its head. The Cat glances at The Wanderer as if just now realizing how misplaced the nomad is, while the Wanderer chuckles warmly and departs from the café.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Lebowski is shocked as The Dude, encouraged, takes a sip of his drink and receives an envelope from Brandt. Inside, The Dude finds a toe with green nail polish. Later, The Dude and Walter are lost in thought at a counter, stirring their coffee. A dripping noise is heard as The Dude sits in a bathtub, spaced out, with a joint in hand. Suddenly, men toss a marmot into the tub, causing chaos. The Dude's car is damaged, and a policeman mockingly presents him with a door handle and mirror. At the bar, The Dude, Walter, and Donny sit silently, each with their drinks. Walter sadly leaves The Dude at the bar. The Stranger, narrator of the film, observes The Dude, who acknowledges the Stranger's out-of-place presence. The Stranger chuckles and leaves, adding an element of bemusement to the scene.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: The Dude looks at The Stranger as if just now noticing how out of place the cowpoke is while the Stranger chuckles indulgently and pushes off from the bar His crinkled eyes settle on the Dude who still staring down at his drink shakes his head The Stranger nods and waiting for his drink looks amiably around the bar We recognize the voice of The Stranger whose narration opened the movie Sam Elliot perhaps with a large Westernstyle mustache and wearing denims a yoked shirt and a cowboy hat He is middleaged amiable craggily handsome Walter sadly shakes his head as they leave the Dude sitting morosely at the bar and he stares The Dude Walter and Donny sit at the bar the Dude with a White Russian Walter with a beer and Donny eating beer nuts A policeman hands the Dude a door handle and an exterior rearview mirror laughing and agreeing broadly while the Dude looks sadly through his window at the policeman rocking back on his heels his raucous laughter muffled by the glass The three men turn to leave and have reached the Dude's car where the driver's side exterior has been scraped raw The marmot splashes frantically biting at the Dude in a frenzy of fearful aggression the Dude screams The Dude looks curiously at the small nattering animal before the man with the string scoops up the marmot and tosses it screaming into the bathtub One of them holds a string at the other end of which a small animal skitters excitedly about the floor as two other men enter behind him After the Dude's outgoing message we hear a dripping noise and the Dude looks stuporously up his head swaying He stares at his toes which protrude from the soapy water splayed against the far side of the tub a joint pinched in one hand a washcloth draped over his head The Dude sits in the bathtub staring stuporously A dripping noise follows Walter calls after him as he looks defiantly around The Dude has left frame A waitress enters The Dude and Walter sit at the counter both staring off into space both absently stirring their coffee with little clinking noises Between thumb and forefinger the Dude holds up the contents of the packagea little toe with emerald green nail polish The Dude undoes the tape with his fingernails and starts to unroll the inner package The wadding undone reveals a smaller wad of gauze taped up inside The Dude frowning untucks its flap takes out some cotton wadding and unrolls it Brandt is handing him a lettersized envelope which is distended by something inside The Dude is encouraged and takes a hurried sip from his drink Lebowski stares at him dumbstruck
